sentence.text: Patient 4 was the unique girl of a nonconsanguineous Turkish couple from the same village.
She was referred at 5 years and 10 months of age for growth retardation and skeletal anomalies (Fig. 1).
Height was 86 cm (−6 SD) and she presented with micromelic dwarfism with short hands and feet, pectus excavatum, pes varus, and bilateral genu valgum and recurvatum.
Cleft palate has been operated and was associated with micrognathia and bifid uvula.
Facial features included a broad nasal root.
She also had bilateral single palmar creases.
No intellectual disability was noticed but gross motor development was delayed.
Hand X-rays showed hyperphalangism of the third and fourth fingers associated with brachymetacarpy.
The middle phalanges of the two to fourth fingers were abnormally shaped and short.
No advanced carpal bone age was noticed but a carpal synostosis between the hamate and capitate bones (Fig. 2).
Spine examination showed a moderate scoliosis (Fig. 3) and pelvis X-ray coxa valga (Fig. 4).
Foot X-rays showed clinodactyly of the fifth toes.
